entry.title: Object of Research or Subject of Argument?
entry.content:
After reading and discussing the articles assigned for this past week. I’m thankful to be somewhat more clear on the differences between object of research and subject of argument.  The corollary between the two is simply that the objects of research generally act as the vehicle through which a historian arrives at his subject of argument.  A subject is wholly unsubstantiated without objects of research, and conversely, objects of research are merely pieces of evidence that necessitate a grander subjective interpretation.
       In the case of Kimberly Gauderman’s article, it is not terribly hard to recognize the objects of research: the women obraje owners and their respective stake in the economy of Quito.  Using the experiences of these women, Gauderman makes a claim to the opposition of patriarchal dominance that has traditionally been afforded to Spanish colonial territories.  It seemed considerably more difficult to identify the objects of research in the book I read for the historical problem paper.   Briefly, the book is about constitutionalism, the amending process, and the way in which amendments serve as a key indicator of changing American political thought.  Unlike either of the two assigned articles, the author chooses to partition his work into chronological divisions, divvying up constitutional amendments into eras of political change.  Therein which, the author narrates his claims by providing a plethora of political anecdotes (meetings, dialogues, conventions, court rulings) that intend to envelop the reader in the author’s main claim.  Are the objects of research these political anecdotes or more broadly and simply, just the entire chronological era of political thought that the author analyzes as divided by chapter?
       Another question that arose to me was whether or not the author’s historiographical approach to the work was considered in analyzing his/her narrative.  The two articles we read for last class used a cultural approach, largely determining how race, gender, or class played into their respective issues/claims.  Instead, the aforementioned book on the amending process recognizes the ‘Great Man’ historical approach, transitioning from one political agent or political event, straight to the next one.  Are these varying approaches relevant in narrative?
       The other reading The Craft of Research was a well-prepared, if somewhat formulaic, look at how to make a legitimate claim with full supporting reasons in the context of a lengthy research essay.  I feel like some of the most important things to take from the reading were the strategies employed by the authors in answering and responding to counter-claims by hypothetical readers.  Sometimes, I feel as if the flaw in my writing is an inability to conform my thoughts to meet the needs of my readers.  The tips offered by Booth are helpful in considering where readers will find problems with your writing, and how to construct appropriate responses to these arguments.

entry.title: If we knew what it was we were doing, it would not be called research, would it?
entry.content:
“One can suggest that the accumulation of small investments could have been an important element in the financing of the district’s main commercial enterprise.”

This week’s readings were all about finding the object and subject of a particular argument. It was also about deciphering the structure that is used in a particular paper. The object of the research is the question that the researcher is trying to answer. The subject of the argument is how the researcher answers the question. The structure is how the researcher frames the narrative to explain their argument. The evidence that they use is how they support the argument that they are trying to explain.

In this week’s readings there were two examples these structures. The first was Kimberly Gauderman’s article on women in textiles in seventeenth century Quito. Gauderman uses a very strict structure that is framed much like a funnel. This structure also helps her to bring together her argument that women’s economic lives were not actually set apart by their gender but by their ability to use economic prosperity and work. But, what gave even more support to Guaderman’s argument was at what cost these women gained their economic stability. Her evidence through court cases and notarial records. These revealed while the elite women who actually owned may not have been involved in the day to day lives of their obraje, there were maestros of lower social status that were involved. Fueled by the demand for their textiles they pushed the indigenous people in their care very hard. An important part of this that is revealed is female-to-female relations. Women were not any easier on their female employees because they were women. In many ways they were harder, accusing them when they became pregnant. Another gender relation that is revealed is that women could hold their own in court as well as men. Gauderman’s article divulges that women gained equality but at the expense of other women’s lives.

In another article written about the working class in Victorian England, it states that E.P. Thompson stated, “everything, from their schools to their shops, their chapels to their amusements, was turned into a battle-ground of class.” E.P. Thompson’s object was what the determining factor behind the English crowd’s riots were. He states how they are not just an outburst determined by nothing. They were hungry because of bread prices and realized their voice in the larger political spectrum. He talks about how in thinking about economy not through capitalism but through a moral economy. Relies more on the cultural and justified reasoning behind economy then a laissez-faire type economy. His ideas are much supported because there were starving populations that did not rise up such as the Irish during the potato blight.


Till next week,
matteavs

entry.title: From Quito to England
entry.content: This week’s class began with a library lesson that seemed invaluable to the production of our theses, but was also overwhelming. The sheer amount of information out there makes me sympathize with Lord Acton, but hopefully once my topic is narrowed down I won’t be so apprehensive about the research. The first reading of the week targeted this task of formulating a research question, and I can’t wait to have this completed. The reading on Quito was quite a bit more manageable than that of the moral economy in England, simply because of length. In the article on Quito, Gauderman’s subject was the refutation of the patriarchal label used to describe gender domination in Spanish colonies. Her article starts with a broad scope and narrows down to prove her point. She lays out women’s roles in the economy in this culture, then moves to the economy of Quito, and finally to textile production. Her method is very effective and her illustrative narration keeps the reader engaged. The object of research is the obraje owners and through the examination of notarial and criminal records she constructs a realistic view of them. This article accurately refuted the widely accepted label of patriarchy in this culture, and thusly her research problem was solved … a historian’s dream. The article regarding the moral economy in England during the 18th century was a little less engaging, but still proved and interesting point. The author refuted the spasmodic character of the food riots and did so through the lens of the worker. He successfully proved these occurrences were often supported by the community and certain officials, thusly legitimizing the workers’ actions. Both pieces were not only professional analyses of history, but were interesting as well. I hope my thesis can achieve this goal.

entry.title: Historical Reasoning
entry.content:
This past weeks readings ranged from a very practical manual on writing history to the always complicated journal article. My favorite piece of the week was Leslie Reagan’s When Abortion was a Crime. To begin with, I found it very interesting that she presented a history from a period that had yet to be thoroughly examined. This lack of examination stemmed from the people assuming that since abortion was illegal, it didn’t happen. This assumption seems silly but until Reagan researched the subject, the question of abortion seems to be unexamined during that period. I think this example of a simple inquest could open up many more fields of history, and also present interesting topics. Her illustrative and reasoning skills are also unbelievable. The amount of information she obtains from her sources is fascinating and would clearly be a great skill to possess in a historian’s toolbox. It seems that she uses both inductive and deductive methods to reach her conclusions and these are used effectively throughout the book. The objectivity with which she tackles the polarizing issue of abortion also shows a mastery of historical writing. Her opinion on the issue is conspicuously absent, and the evidence for her analysis is rock solid.

The journal article addressed the unbelievably complex concept of structure and provided a better “definition” of what that was. It seems to me that the concept of structures is a web of interaction with no discernible start or end, thusly making it quite dynamic. I look forward to gaining further understanding on this topic.

entry.title: Is the foreign so foreign?
entry.content:
“Structures then are “virtual” and are put into practice in the production and reproduction of social life.”

The Leslie Reagan book in an essence describes the idea of history being a foreign country. The vocabulary and their view on life were completely different. But, through the interpretation that Raegan gives, she is able to give understanding and significance to a time that is foreign to the modern reader. She is able to point out what is significant in that time and then come up with a thesis that is relevant in a modern perspective. She is able to take a study that is centered when abortion was a crime and then make conclusions to when it became legal. She is able to give a perspective on that change that is well thought out and shows the positive and negative changes that occurred because of the legalization. This is the responsibility of the historian to take the foreign country and interpret. To give their interpretation of the events in the most unbiased way possible. Inevitably it will come out, and that is what makes historiography interesting. It is what historians do with the research they have in presenting it in their final product.

In Sewall’s discussion of structure one of the first points he talks about is how structure can be limiting in thinking about the past. One of the best quotes he talks about this is, “A social Science trapped in an unexamined metaphor of structure tends to reduce actors to cleverly programmed automatons.” This is a huge boundary to get over as a historian. To give people of the past real human emotions. They were in some ways very much like modern humans. They had thoughts and feelings. These emotions effect their decisions, which in turn would have affected the process of events following these decisions.

Anthony Gidden’s idea of structure was the most useful to determining the importance of structure. Especially in the form of resources. Gidden’s best quote was when he stated; “resources are anything that can serve as a source of power in social interactions.” Another quote that helped to not just explain Gidden’s own ideas about structure but Sewell’s was “Structures are not the patterned social practices that make up social systems, but the principles that pattern these practices.” The metaphor of the working class in England could work in this situation. For the point of structure it is not the actual social structure of that society it was the decisions and then the eventual revolution that put them in that situation. Gidden puts it very simply as the process that is the structure. This fits into agency because agency then is the situation that the structure has put them in.

Till next week,
matteavs

entry.title: Blog 3
entry.content:
William Sewell lays out a much more complex theory of structure than I had considered last week.  In his view, every structure that controls some aspect of social life can also be seen as structuring some other aspect.  Thus, structures can be seen as numerous and overlapping in many respects.  Sewell’s conceptualization of heterogeneous structures plays heavily into his determination to prove structural change is possible.  Indeed, Sewell puts together a formulaic argument based on his proposed five axioms, which posits a sustaining schemas/resources duality that control social action.  Structural change is possible because structures are a product of the social action that they control; yet that production is neither automatic nor singularly controlled.
        In my last blog, I talked a little bit about how a government could be seen as a limiting structure in its tension with personal agency.  Thus, it was refreshing to see Sewell discuss it, especially in terms of how structures harbor power, though may not be extremely well entrenched in social life.  Sewell describes the political ‘state’ as relatively near the surface of social life, which to me means that political structures are normally fragile despite their large power allocations.  Sewell uses the state analogy to show that the durability of a social structure is determined more by the structure’s depth than its power.
       Sewell’s interpretation of agency as a constituent to, rather than in opposition with, structure is confusing to me considering all we talked about in class.  Sewell says that the “capacity for agency is as much a given for humans as the capacity for respiration.”  Perhaps the capacity is there, but structural limitations work to oppose agency to such a degree, I don’t really see how one can say that structure and agency work in accordance.
       Finally, Leslie Reagan’s book When Abortion Was A Crime was an enjoyable read, as I felt that her narrative voice spoke for her rather than any pre-conceived bias.  I honestly don’t know if Leslie Reagan is pro-choice or pro-life, but most importantly, it doesn’t really matter.  It was nice to read the history of a controversial present-day issue, presented in terms of anecdotal historical evidence.
Reagan uses a mixture of deductive and inductive reasoning to reconstruct the societal happenings that occurred as a reaction to the criminalization of abortion.  The information Reagan could gleam from the context of a conversation was intriguing in and of itself.  If Reagan hadn’t provided all the stories/conversations that she did, I think her history of abortion as a crime would have been limited and incomplete, simply because of the amount she interpreted from those conversations.

entry.title: Structure vs Agency
entry.content:
Structure vs Agency. The journal article on structure and agency was interesting and reminded me of a debate that helped me understand the concepts. As the author indicated trying to understand structure can be difficult, but when an example is applied it becomes much clearer. The debate focused around the amount of structure and agency within the lives of African American slaves in the south. A historian by the name of Eugene Genovese argued in his book Roll, Jordan, Roll: The World the Slaves Made (1974), that slaves in the South possessed agency within their lives (or some amount of freedom of choice) as evidenced by slave culture and religion. He argued that even when families were broken up other males would step in to fill the role of the protector. Wilma Dunaway wrote that very little agency existed in the life of slaves because slavery in itself was the equivalent of “social death.” I thought Dunaway won the debate when she pointed that Genovese’s agency argument was based on the model of the large plantation with lots of slaves, when in reality the majority of slaves were held on small farms in small numbers. Anyway that example helped me understand the two concepts. I have a new understanding on how the two are linked. You cannot measure one without the existence of the other and we should strive to understand the structure of the subjects and events we study.
Leslie Reagan’s, When Abortion was a Crime, was an outstanding example of how to interpret data as presented by understanding the context of the conversations. She learned more by what was not said, than said. For example she understood that for the actual procedure to be referred to in code or to be left unspoken, was an indicator of prevalence. My only issue with that as I so ineloquently stated in class was that the people being interviewed in the inquest already understood the subject matter which might explain why they didn’t completely articulate the subject matter. That in itself caused zero problems for me because of how airtight the remainder of her research was. I hope I can put together a piece of slam dunk history like that one day. Talk to you in a couple of weeks. –Paul.

entry.title: Historiography 2
entry.content:
Historiography 2-Blog 2

Mark Bevir stated, “We can say that the working out of objectivity is itself a profoundly historical process.”

This is very true given the readings and what has been stated in class. From the in class time from last week there seemed to come about two ways of looking at history. One through Historical Materialism the other through Historical Culture. From looking at this it would seem that the most egocentric way of looking at history is through Historical Materialism. Through culturism the historian interprets the culture within its own world. It does not try to compare and contrast itself to another culture. In materialism, there is always going to be a comparison against the most technologically advanced country. But, what is that technology is negative. This is what makes both sides objective. Because a historian cannot put himself or herself into the past it is physically impossible. Also the historian cannot investigate a country, which had a lower living standard than the richest country in the world at the time.

One of the ways that I appreciated Bevir’s comments was through his idea that, “Of course, as interpretations reveal the particular character of a fact, they often partially define the way we regard the fact.” This is very true in that what the historian states in his work will shape the reader’s perception of that event until he or she reads another work about that subject and it may change.

I am reminded through this of how this could work in a primary source work where the historian is the self telling the story. After the Battle of Gettysburg, there were many interpretations of who shot the first shot there. But, the one that was written was from the Confederate side that said the Seventh Tennessee Regiment of Archer’s Brigade shot down one of Beaufort’s cavalry. Because this was the only thing written about that particular part of the battle it was accepted. But, many years later many more accounts were written and it was officially decided that is was actually one of Beaufort’s cavalry. Because of the Tennesseans bias toward making their contribution to the battle bigger they changed their interpretation and thereby changing history.

Through the contributions of historiography, it has now become a wide field that can be argued over and interpreted time and time again.

Till next week,
matteavs

entry.title: History 307 is a Foreign Country
entry.content:
This past week’s discussion began with something rather comfortable to me, footnotes. After feeling rather intellectually inadequate due to the pre-class readings, this was a welcome topic. We settled on the notion that footnotes establish the author’s credibility as well as competence. We moved on to the affect the publishing industry has upon academic research and work. The ever present drive within (publication) companies for money seems to have changed the atmosphere of academic work in a negative aspect. The researcher not only desires to be published but usually needs to be in order to continue their profession. This need empowers the publisher and allows them to influence the content of the final product (i.e. footnotes, subject matter). Dr. Black then explained the levels of employment within the University in regards to professors and I honestly had no idea of the struggle for PhD’s to not only gain tenure, but a reasonable living! It explained a lot about the professors I have had in the past three years and I think I could guess which ones had more stable positions. This all related to the relationship between structure and agency in historiography. This publishing/university structure was deemed to inhibit the historian’s agency, and in order to have more of a free reign upon deciphering history, this must change.

This discussion then morphed into one that incorporated the readings, a time I was not looking forward to. While feeling like a lost puppy, we stumbled upon the topic of historical materialism vs. idealism. We defined materialism to mean the search for tangible explanations, in regards to historical causes, while idealism deals with the abstract. An example of materialism would be the Marxist approach to history and one of the readings addressed a specific group of scholars in Britain that followed this stringently. I feel I am oversimplifying or under-qualified, but I think I would take both approaches into consideration while writing history (Is this possible?). Our conversation then dealt with the derivation of meaning within history, and the cultural lens that must be present to do this. It seems that history is all about context, and Dr. Black then posed the question: Can a man accurately write the history of a woman? While the sexes may differ and this has caused inaccurate historical accounts in the past, an objective approach could definitely allow a history to be written. As long as the male not only considers the culture and structures present, but also the woman’s place in it, then it could be done.

I feel I have rambled/summarized enough and welcome enlightenment provided by my classmates and teacher.

entry.title: Blog 2
entry.content:
For this past week’s literature I decided to take notes as I was reading through it, primarily in order to help myself recognize some of the larger and interconnected ideas.  During discussion we didn’t really have time to delve into Mark Bevir’s ‘web of interpretation’ ideas, though I found them be pretty interesting.  Bevir holds that historians seek to establish a web of interpretation, formulated in terms of agreed facts, to help explain past events.  The interpretation should be analogous to a web, in that it should be extensive and all encompassing.  In fact, I think Bevir used the terms ‘fruitful’ and ‘open’ to describe any historical interpretation.  It is also crucial to recognize the fluidity of any possible interpretation of the past.  Inevitably, all interpretations and theories are subject to outside criticisms.  Yet, if one has established the fruitful and fluid ‘web’ of interpretation Bevir speaks of, it should be easy to incorporate opposing arguments into your own.  I wonder if Bevir would have said that historical knowledge (rooted in historical interpretation) only ever advances forward as the best, most successful interpretations continue to improve by incorporating or overcoming criticisms?
As to what we discussed in class, I’ve been thinking a bit about personal agency in history and its tensions with structure.  I know to exemplify ‘structure’ we provided such ideas as funding models and disciplinary standards, which definitely do limit one’s capacity to act.  However, when I hear ‘structure’ that limits one’s ability to act, I can’t help but think of the monolithic American government.  In a supposed free society, our government tightly watches those who have the greatest agency.  For example, consider Nixon’s paranoia with John Lennon and Lennon’s simple message of peace.  The American government tapped Lennon’s phone and had men follow him, primarily because they feared his capacity to act, his ability to impact society.  Marxist history or ‘history from below’ would have one believe that limited agency is a product of your social position, rooted in an economic framework.  In my life, I feel as if I have enjoyed a great number of freedoms that have allowed me to act and affect things external to myself.  Yet, if the government intends to strip our freedoms away and keep us tied down by a massive institute, which only has its best interests in mind, what hope is there for our personal agency within society?




I had to watch a documentary on Lennon for my Cinema Studies/American Politics class, so sorry about the above rant.  See you guys Wednesday.

entry.title: week 2 - Marxists reading
entry.content:
First, Marxists whether historians,sociologists or philosophers, all talk of the same thing, that is economic classes that exist in the society and how the poor are being oppressed by the elite. In this article Marxist historians try to advocate for social change by contributing to class consciousness and recovering of past experiences. Take for example,trying to understand a culture totally different from your own, even if one tries to socialize with people from that culture one can never really know exactly the ongoings of that society because we are socialized differently. Take myself as an example, an international student from Africa, first time in America, nomatter how hard i will try to understand the American culture i can never really understand all of it. Which takes us back to last week’s discussion truth and accuracy. How much truth is there in historical documents and how much of it is just mere speculation? I believe that the deeper one goes with their research, the less truth there is to it and the more speculation there is. I really dont mean to be too skeptical but historians tend to take a side nomatter how unbiased they try to be,for example, the Marxists never really liked the elites, so obviousy they would take the side fo the “opressed”. entry.title: Objectivity
entry.content: Mark Bevir might be guilty of sophistry, but if not that, he is certainly guilty of first degree verbosity. To quote the great amateur historian Forrest Gump, “I am not a smart man,” but I will attempt to comment on/interpret his article. Let me start by saying that the Bevir piece had more -isms than my Philosophy class last semester (God I hated that class), back to Bevir and objectivity.  “No existing past exists in which to judge rival interpretations” that is why we lose all objectivity, relativism aside?  I think I understand what that means but am concerned about why it is a serious challenge to Bevir’s notion of objectivity. If I study a primary source historical document, interpret, and then write about it. My analysis will certainly be based on my current day experience, it is unavoidable. Does that mean I am not objective just because there are no interpretations from another time in which to compare my work? I agree with Bevir that like the scientists he mentions our theories should not be compared to prior work but to other work of our time. Comparisons to a prior time would help in determining the motives and value systems of the earlier historian; for example examining the influence of pseudo-science like Social Darwinism on an early 20th century historian’s interpretation of the Spanish American War.  What influences my work today and what might future historians say about it? I don’t care about future critics of my objectivity because the audience I am most concerned about lives in the 21st Century.  I also agree with Bevir that when we compare our work with others we can find common ground or overlapping theories on which to try and determine fact. For me it is as simple as this, strive to be 100% objective and 100% accurate but know it is a little bit like an irrational number at some point you need to round it off and except your answer as the most accurate possible.  While complicated the article does make for an interesting debate, I just wish he would have written it in language that Forrest would have understood.

entry.title: Blog 1
entry.content:
Hey guys, I’m just here to briefly comment on last week’s readings and discussion.  So part one of The Modern Historiography Reader was a collection of four historian’s viewpoints on the scholarship of history.  Wow, that sounds extremely interesting……  The first three authors pose the essential question of what exactly history is and what it is professional historians should or should not do.  Lord Acton’s dilemma, in which he grappled with a moral obligation to point out the uniting and associated conditions of civilization, was intriguing when you consider what Cronon wrote in 2004.  In order to gain a real understanding of any past event, you have to analyze how each social/political aspect of the past relates to one another.  Like Cronon suggests, all historical knowledge is relational and the past is only a product of multicausal explanations.  My favorite article of part one was Carl Becker’s construction of Mr. Everyman, whom in some ways employs history and historical research in his everyday life.  Becker seemed to make the vocation more accessible by showing how most everyone will at some point make use of critical research methods that characterize the historical field.  Last of the four articles is Bonnie Smith’s “What is a Historian?”  Studying languages during youth, as the nineteenth century adolescences did, would have been the best way to prepare for a profession in history.  In today’s world, having a familiarity with multiple languages would obviously be very beneficial to an aspiring historian.  Smith also speaks of the broad gender relations that have characterized the professional world of history.  I had no idea that many historians were considered “so gendered in a way” because of the significance of their wives to their historical authorship.
          The fifth part of The Modern Historiography Reader was intriguing enough, mainly because I related to James Robinson’s outlook on ‘The New History’.  Don’t we all hope that in some way our historical writing could be relevant to current times?  I feel like I need to write a history that is compelling enough, through fact alone, to make a reader potentially change his/her perspective on any given political or social issue.
          Lastly, the Carnegie Essays on the Doctorate provided an interesting depiction of the requirements and work necessary to become part of the historian’s guild.  The way in which Cronon divvies up the shared values of the ‘historian’ helps one understand the intricacies of the professional doctorate.  Additionally, the information in the article helps shape my personal opinion of what would make a good senior dissertation topic.  For example, if one holds that history is inevitably written from a particular point of view and that this in turn shapes histories by correlating it with present politics, problems arise in potential topics.  In fact, it becomes a question or whether one could ever even delve into a historical topic of recent happening without entirely too much bias or subjectivity.

entry.title: Historiography 1
entry.content:
Historiography I

Leopold von Ranke stated, “the purpose of history was to clarify our notion of the origin and nature of the state.” What are the roles of the writers of history, historians? What makes them qualified to do this?

These questions were all answered by the reading this week and through our class time. Historians are not supposed to just explain history but interpret it. What this actually means has evolved since the professions birth in the nineteenth century. One evolution that has made an extreme impact on myself is what James Harvey Robinson describes. He gives a very good descriptive analysis of the shift in the history field from what we described in class as the Great Man History to wanting to learn about the everyman and how he lived his life. He also describes the shift from the interest in the sensational to the interest in the normal.

William Cronon, in his essay listed the qualifications that make up the profession and then presented his own thoughts on what should make up the training to be admitted to the historical guild. What makes Cronon’s thoughts interesting and challenging are not the list of qualifications but his own ideas. For myself they challenged my own ideas of training I will need. Cronon specifically talked about the Public History field, which is what I want to go into. He challenged the divergence that many public historians feel separates them from academia. He believes that public historians could have an academic training to understand the beginnings of the history in which they are presenting.

One topic that was discussed in a majority of the essays was the role of bias in history and accepting the natural bias that occurs in the writing of history. For me the bias of history is what makes the profession interesting and fresh. It is what keeps the profession going and limitless. Topics such as the Civil War and World War II are written about over and over again. But, what makes each work refreshing is the bias that occurs which makes it different from all works that came before it. Historians then analyze these works and write their own that will be analyzed in the future.

The key part of this is originality for the historians to keep asking new questions and interpreting in new ways. As William Cronon states, “Interpretation is as important as explanation.” Historians can all explain the events that they study. But, what sets them apart is how they analyze them and present it to the reader. Out of this interpretation questions are asked such as: “What is the larger picture?” or “Why is this important?” We also learn about the historian’s own time from their writings. For example we were able to learn about the nineteenth century and the moral codes of the time through Lord Acton’s writings.

As Carl Becker states, “History is the memory of things said and done.”

Till next week,
matteavs

entry.title: Historiography I
entry.content:
Historiography- The study of how historians do history; that sounds about as exciting as watching paint dry, but I must admit that as an historian apprentice, I found parts of this week’s readings intriguing. I particularly liked the William Cronon essay and his discussion on objectivity. While absolute objectivity should be our goal, I think it is important to realize that it is unattainable. We will never be able to study our subject matter and leave our personal beliefs and culture behind. As Cronan points out realizing historians are biased helps us to critically analyze their work, and then seek the “other” point of view creating a broader view and hopefully a deeper understanding of the issue.
Understanding our bias should not prevent us from being as objective as possible. For example, I am a Coast Guard retiree and very proud of my service and the Coast Guard’s history and most of its missions. My senior thesis will probably deal with Coast Guard history. So if through the course of my research I discover something relevant to my subject matter but also unfavorable towards the Coast Guard would I publish the unfavorable information? Absolutely, for two reasons: One, because it is the right thing to do and secondly, because I would control the initial message. Another example from the other direction; I personally feel that the Coast Guard drug interdiction mission is a total failure and an enormous waste of tax payer dollars. Were I to write on the history of this mission I would include the proponents argument as a way to strengthen my own thesis. If I found that the evidence did not support my thesis and the mission is a successful one, then I would change my position and write it that way. Again because it is the right thing to do and also when I write something I want it to be as strong as possible, not necessarily bulletproof but praiseworthy. When I say the “right thing to do” it means the right thing as a reputable historian, not in the Lord Acton moral sense of right. I believe he crosses a line with his bias by instilling a pre-supposed moral code onto his subject matter. This could result in making the research less valid and more fantastical. For example, were Lord Acton to have discovered a primary source document which put his moral code and belief system in jeopardy would he have given it the proper credence? I think not.
Cronon’s comment concerning journalists writing history was interesting because the best history book I read this year was “Unbroken” written by journalist Laura Hillenbrand. Her research was outstanding and the narrative of Louis Zamperini a WWII POW was very compelling, proving that you don’t have to be a historian to do great history.

That’s all for this week.
